captions.text:
Well, I don&#39;t know how precisely one gets South 
of Midnight; that&#39;s like saying half past 10 miles

away, but it is a game set in the American Deep 
South, which is presumably south of most things,

so fine, you win this round, Compulsion 
Games, developer of We Happy Few. Oh,

that&#39;s strange. I can&#39;t seem to find anything 
in the marketing copy of South of Midnight

referencing that it&#39;s from the developer of We 
Happy Few. Why&#39;s that, developer of We Happy Few,

Compulsion Games? Don&#39;t you want people to 
remember that you developed We Happy Few,

developer of We Happy Few, Compulsion Games? 
Or do you not want people to harp on the fact

that you&#39;re no more from the American Deep 
South than you were from England? Compulsion

are still as Canadian as they were last time, 
which is presumably why the contemporary Deep

South they depict here is all down-home folksy 
magical realism and has a surprising absence of

Walmarts. But let&#39;s be fair. We Happy Few had a 
pretty good aesthetic and story if you could get

past the gameplay being four pints of tosh in 
a three-pint tosh receptacle, and just to skip

to the end for a moment, it&#39;s the aesthetic 
and story that recommend South of Midnight.

The gameplay&#39;s complete fucking dishwater, but 
hey, dishwater fills a space. Specifically,

a space the precise dimensions of a kitchen sink, 
but I&#39;m getting too far ahead. South of Midnight

follows Hazel Flood, a young track star in a 
dying small town who goes on a quest to rescue her

mother after her house is washed away in a storm 
and enters a world of talking animals and magical

realism. Ah, ah, Hazel Flood, Dorothy Gale, house 
removed by namesake weather phenomenon. This is

rather overt Wizard of Oz parallelism, isn&#39;t it? 
Except ultimately, Hazel is not so much brought to

a fantasy magical realist world as made aware of 
the fact that she&#39;s already in one because she&#39;s

secretly a destined hero called a Weaver who 
uses mystical powers to unpick the bad vibes

created from deep-set pain and trauma, which 
in practical terms means smacking the shit out

of metaphorical monsters in an assuredly very 
analogous sort of way. Through this method,

Hazel explores the hidden darkness at the heart 
of the world in which she lives in a story that,

at its core, is about emotional pain and how 
we deal with it. Pretty universal themes. Yes,

I too push people away because I&#39;m afraid 
of turning into a giant monster owl.

And when I say darkness at the heart of the 
world, I mean really fucking dark. The parallels

with Wizard of Oz kind of fall away; the witch 
being crushed by a falling house is replaced

by poverty-stricken children being crushed 
by generational trauma. The dead baby is the

absolute least of it, but you&#39;d be surprised how 
much more wholesome a horrifying story of child

abuse and murder can become when it&#39;s narrated 
with a folksy Southern drawl. Makes me wonder

how far you could take that. &quot;Well, I guess 
no one ever done taught that Jeffrey Dahmer

feller that drain-cleaning chemicals ain&#39;t got 
no business inside a human skull.&quot; I apologize

for that. And for everything, generally. So, 
as I say, South of Midnight is very strong

on aesthetic. The environments choked with 
generic black-and-red evil corrupting matter

that clears out to be replaced with blooming 
flowers every time Hazel smacks the shit out

of enough things might be a little bit on the 
nose, not to mention a bit tonally off, since

the answer to the trauma demons created by small 
children getting the shit smacked out of them with

birch twigs is apparently to smack the shit out 
of them some more but benevolently this time.

Which might as well bring us to the gameplay 
in all its dish-sterilizing functionality.

The format is pure ghost train ride. Hazel 
advances through a linear sequence of areas,

completing platforming, climbing, 
and environmental puzzle sequences,

looking for entanglements of bad vibes to 
purge. And sometimes, after we do that,

Uncle Remus comes back on and tells us another 
chapter in the story of how Old Mama Cyrus done

tortured her sister to death with electrified 
nipple clamps or whatever appalling trauma lies

at the heart of the current area and upcoming boss 
fight. Fine. But at some point, the delivery man

must have shown up at the door saying, &quot;Hey, I&#39;ve 
brought you the minimum amount of combat required

to call yourself an action-adventure game, where 
do you want it?&quot; Well, there&#39;s those boss fights

with the trauma monsters. &quot;Ooh, I dunno, love; 
the boss fights can&#39;t be the only combat in the

game unless you fall under category F subsection 
9 of the Shadow of the Colossus clause. Why don&#39;t

you sprinkle a bunch of token arena fights 
with the boss&#39;s mooks across the levels?&quot;

Mooks? Why the fuck would Old Mama Cyrus have 
mooks? She&#39;s a disarmingly pleasant, homely

old dear who happens to have murdered a close 
relative; she didn&#39;t run a fucking meth empire.

&quot;Look, lady, I&#39;m not story department, I&#39;m just 
telling you this combat&#39;s gotta go somewhere or

you can take it up with the union.&quot; And so, every 
time we un-trauma an area, a bunch of painfully

generic, spiky, black badness demons come out of 
the woodwork like the token hitherto unestablished

sex partner at the end of the first act of a 
Cinemax erotic thriller, and we&#39;re obliged to go

through the routine of whacking them with sticks 
and dodging when they attack so that we might

live to whack them with sticks another day, and 
it&#39;s all terribly uninspired. You could replace

it all with a frantic masturbation minigame and 
say Hazel suffers from unmedicated nymphomania

and very little would change, except probably 
the age rating. Shame, really, because the boss

fights are pretty good. In fact, I might say that 
South of Midnight features the best integration

of gameplay and music that I&#39;ve seen in quite a 
while. I&#39;d be fighting the hideous electrified

nipple monster version of Old Mama Cyrus&#39; 
sister, and there&#39;ll be a toe-tapping rhythm

and blues number playing with lyrics about how 
Old Mama Cyrus done overdid the mammary voltage.

Again, bit on the nose, perhaps, but I swear what 
I&#39;m doing in organic gameplay syncs up with the

music more often than not, and yes, it is a ghost 
train ride, and as such, the pacing is always

firmly under the game&#39;s control like a turkey&#39;s 
gullet in the fist of an unsympathetic farmhand,

but still. If you&#39;d told me after I played Sonic 
Unleashed that one day I&#39;d play a game that

accompanied standard combat with up-tempo jazz 
music and I&#39;d find it not completely irritating,

I&#39;d have said, &quot;Boy, coming back from the 
future to tell me that suggests a severe

deficiency in big-picture thinking.&quot; But if 
we&#39;re inching our way towards a conclusion here,

I&#39;d say I recommend South of Midnight for 
its faults because it&#39;s got decent writing,

a strong aesthetic, and gameplay that at worst 
fills the gaps. It&#39;s still kind of a shame that

all a game needs to do these days to stand out is 
have a distinct personality and actually be about

something, even if the intended tone wavers 
about like a set of windscreen wipers. So,

yeah. Getting better, Compulsion Games! Solid 
writing, great music, dishwater gameplay, but hey,

dishwater&#39;s a nice thing to have around 
if you need to do some washing up. I mean,

in contrast, We Happy Few&#39;s gameplay 
was a kitchen sink full of ocelot sick.
